installNodeAgentReminderBanner.primaryText: Node agent needs to be installed on some nodes
installNodeAgentReminderBanner.nodeAgentMustBeInstallToUpgradeYba: Node agent manages communication between universe nodes and YugabyteDB Anywhere, and must be installed on all nodes before you can upgrade to future versions of YugabyteDB Anywhere.
installNodeAgentReminderBanner.waysToInstallNodeAgent: YugabyteDB Anywhere can automatically install node agent on universes that require it, or you can install node agent manually.
installNodeAgentReminderBanner.howToManuallyInstallNodeAgent: To manually install node agent, navigate to the universe and choose Actions>More>Install Node Agent.
installNodeAgentReminderBanner.automaticInstallationsInProgress: Automatic installation of node agent is in progress. Click View Node Agents to see which nodes have node agent installed.
installNodeAgentReminderBanner.manuallyUnregisteredNodeAgent: If you manually removed node agent on any nodes, then you must also manually reinstall by navigating to the universe and choosing Actions>More>Install Node Agent. The automatic installation of node agent will not reinstall node agent on those nodes for you.
installNodeAgentReminderBanner.someNodeAgentsAreNotFunctional: We found some universes where node agent is not functional. Click View Node Agents to find the problem nodes, verify they fulfill the <nodeAgentPrereqDocsLink>node prerequisites</nodeAgentPrereqDocsLink> and retry the installation by choosing Actions>Reinstall Node Agent.

useSystemdReminderBanner.primaryText: Some of your universes use cron to manage nodes.
useSystemdReminderBanner.additionalDetailText: <paragraph>Cron-based universes will no longer be supported in YugabyteDB Anywhere v2025.2 and later. Before you can upgrade to v2025.2, you must upgrade cron-based universes to systemd.</paragraph><paragraph>To do this, navigate to the universe and choose <bold>Actions>Upgrade to Systemd</bold></paragraph>

initiateModal.title: Switchover to DR Replica
initiateModal.titleTooltip: <paragraph>Switch the DR primary with the DR replica after waiting for replication drain so there will be no data loss.</paragraph>Replication drain allows the replication on the DR replica to catch up with the DR primary and be fully synchronized before initiating switchover.

success.taskSuccess: Switchover completed. <universeLink><bold>{{sourceUniverseName}}</bold></universeLink> is now your DR primary.

selectTargetUniverse.isTransactionalConfigTooltip: <paragraph>YBA support for transactional atomicity has the following constraints:<orderedList><listItem>The minimum YBDB version that supports transactional atomicity is 2.18.1.0-b1.</listItem><listItem>PITR must be enabled on the target universe.</listItem><listItem>Neither the source universe nor the target universe is a participant in any other xCluster configuration.</listItem></orderedList>You may find further information on this feature on our<xClusterDocLink> public docs.</xClusterDocLink></paragraph>
selectTargetUniverse.backupStorageConfigNote: <paragraph><bold>Note!</bold> If the tables to replicate are not empty on this source universe, ensure that the <bold> backup storage config can be accessed from both source and target universe </bold> for creating an initial full copy. Particularly, <bold>Network File System (NFS)</bold> based storage configs may not be accessible from universes in different regions. In that case, refer to the <ybAdminDocsLink>documentation for creating replication using yb-admin</ybAdminDocsLink>.</paragraph>
selectTargetUniverse.fullCopyNote: <bold>What is a full copy?</bold><paragraph>A full copy of your source universe is created to bring the target universe to the same checkpoint before turning on async replication. First, YBAnywhere creates a backup of the source universe. Then it restores the backup to the target universe. Hence the need to ensure the backup storage config is accessible from both source & target universe. If the tables selected for xcluster replication are empty on the source universe, no full copy creation is required.</paragraph>

upgradeModal.title: Upgrade Linux version
upgradeModal.infoContent:
Note!

The process of upgrading the Universe OS is time-consuming, as it involves upgrading one node at a time through a rolling upgrade approach. Each individual node upgrade consists of detaching the current boot disk, attaching a new boot disk, and then rebooting the node.

Throughout this entire process, no other Universe operations can take place, but your application will remain intact. It is advisable to upgrade during off-peak hours.

upgradeModal.verifyImageText: It is recommended to verify that the selected image can boot successfully on a standalone VM with the same instance type as the universe before initiating the upgrade.

tooltips.logCatalog: Log statements for the PostgreSQL system catalog relations in pg_catalog. Disable this option to reduce noise in the log.
tooltips.logClient: Log messages directly to clients such as ysqlsh and psql for debugging. When enabled, you can set the level of logs that are output using pgaudit.log_client.
tooltips.logLevel: Set the severity level of logs displayed in clients when pgaudit.log_client is on.Will need to set an extra flag log_min_messages for all the severity levels to work. By default only LOG or WARNING will work without needing the flag log_min_messages
tooltips.logParameter: Include parameters passed with the statement. Parameters are provided in .csv format after the statement text.
tooltips.logParameterMaxSize: Maximum size, in bytes, of parameters to include. Parameters longer than this value are replaced with <long param suppressed>.
tooltips.logRelation: Create separate log entries for each relation (TABLE, VIEW, etc.) referenced in a SELECT or DML statement. This is a shortcut for exhaustive logging without using object audit logging.
tooltips.logStatement: Include the statement text and parameters.
tooltips.logStatementOnce: Statement text (and, if enabled, parameters) are included with every log entry. Enable this option to only include them with the first log entry for a statement or sub-statement combination. This results in less verbose logging, but can make it more difficult to determine the statement that generated a log entry.
tooltips.logRow: Include the rows retrieved or affected by a statement.
tooltips.exportLog: Forward audit log to your preferred 3rd party log management tool such as Datadog, Splunk, AWS CloudWatch, or GCP Cloud Logging. The audit logs are always available for download using the API regardless of whether export is enabled or otherwise.

OIDCMetadataModal.title: Add OIDC Provider Configuration
OIDCMetadataModal.helpText:
Paste the content of your identity provider's OIDC configuration document (in JSON format) into the field below.

The document contains key-value pairs with details about the OIDC provider's configuration, including all necessary endpoints and public key location information. Learn More

infos.clientID: The unique identifier of your manually created client application in the Identity Provider
infos.clientSecret: The password or secret for authenticating your Yugabyte client application with your Identity Provider
infos.discoveryURL: Endpoint that validates all authorization requests. This can be found in discovery document
infos.emailAttribute: Scope containing email ID of the user
infos.refreshTokenURL: Provide the endpoint that will be used for re-fetching the access token
infos.defaultRole: The "Default Role" sets privileges for users who are not explicitly registered in YugabyteDB Anywhere
infos.defaultRoleHelpText: When off, OIDC individual users are used for role authentication
infos.readOnly: The "Read Only" role allows users to log in and provides read-only privileges
infos.connectOnly: The "Connect Only" role allows users to log in and edit their own profile
infos.groupClaim: Provide the claim keyword in a user's OIDC ID token that contains the list of the user's OIDC groups
infos.jwtTokenURL: Option to display button to retrieve the JWT token

LDAP.title: LDAP Configuration
LDAP.groupMemeberAttribute: Attribute that will be used to find the list of groups that is a member of

infos.ldapURL: LDAP URL must be a valid URL with port number, Ex:- 0.0.0.0:0000
infos.ldapSecurity: Configure the LDAP server connection to use LDAPS (SSL) or LDAP with StartTLS (TLS) encryption
infos.tlsProtocol: Configure the TLS Protocol Version to be used in case of StartTLS or LDAPS
infos.ldapBaseDN: Base of the DN for LDAP queries. Will be appended to the user name at login time to query the LDAP server
infos.ldapDNPrefix: LDAP DN Prefix will be set to CN= by default if not provided
infos.customerUUID: Unique ID of the customer in case of multi-tenant platform
infos.searchAndBind: Mechanism used to bind to the LDAP server
infos.searchAttribute: Attribute that will be used to search for the user in the LDAP server
infos.searchFilter: Filter that will be used to narrow down the search for the user inside specific LDAP groups. Either search attribute or filter should be specified.
infos.serviceAccountName: Bind DN will be used to login to the service account
infos.connectOnly: Users with ConnectOnly role cannot see any information other than their own profile information
infos.groupSearchFilter:
Use {username} to refer to the user CN
Example: (&(objectClass=group)(member=CN={username},OU=Users,DC=yugabyte,DC=com)
infos.groupSearchBaseDN: Base DN used to search for user group membership

resilience.title: YugabyteDB 101
resilience.msg: Resiliency is the ability to withstand and recover from various types of failures. A resilient database system has a high fault tolerance. It is designed to maintain data integrity, accessibility, and continuity of operations, even in the face of adverse events.

infoTooltips.guidedMode: Guided mode uses the selected cluster's fault tolerance to suggest optimal setup requirements for achieving the intended outcome.
infoTooltips.freeForm: Free form flow is optimal for users who want to create unique cluster setups. (Advanced)

dedicatedNodes.toggle: Allocate dedicated nodes to master servers
dedicatedNodes.disabledToolip: you need atleast {{nodeCount}} nodes to enable this option
dedicatedNodes.title: Advanced Configuration
dedicatedNodes.helpText: Optimize performance by allocating dedicated resources for metadata operations.
dedicatedNodes.helpTextLink: Note! This will increase the number nodes in your cluster. Learn more.
dedicatedNodes.helpText1: Improve metadata and cluster coordination capacity by placing master servers on dedicated nodes.
dedicatedNodes.helpText2: Recommended for deployments with many databases or very large table counts.
dedicatedNodes.tooltip:
Master node count is system-assigned and is equal to the cluster’s replication factor. This is to maintain consensus and fault tolerance.

Learn more

replicationFactorCard.title: Setup Requirements
replicationFactorCard.azNotAvailable: Not available during availability zone outage

replicationFactorInfoModal.title: YugabyteDB 101
replicationFactorInfoModal.rfFactorAns: YugabyteDB replicates data across fault domains (which, depending on the deployment, could be nodes, availability zones, or regions) in order to tolerate faults. The replication factor (RF) is the number of copies of data in a YugabyteDB cluster.
replicationFactorInfoModal.FtAndRf: Correlation between Fault Tolerance and Replication Factor
replicationFactorInfoModal.FtAndRfAns: To achieve a FT of <highlight>f</highlight> fault domains, the primary cluster has to be configured with a RF of at least <highlight>2f + 1</highlight>.
replicationFactorInfoModal.tip: Tip! When using Guided Mode, the required replication factor is automatically configured and applied based on your selected fault tolerance.
replicationFactorInfoModal.learn: Learn more about Replication Factor and Fault Tolerance.

prefferedInfoModal.title: YugabyteDB 101
prefferedInfoModal.prefferedQues: What is the preferred availability zone?
prefferedInfoModal.prefferedAns: The preferred availability zones handle all read and write requests from your client application. For lower latencies and best performance, set the availability zones closest to your application as preferred.
prefferedInfoModal.links: <a1>Learn more about preferred availability zone</a1> and <a2>how to select ranking.</a2>
prefferedInfoModal.note:
Note:

  • If no zone is set as preferred, client requests are equally distributed across all zones.
  • Certain exceptions, such as follower reads, will diverge read requests.
  • You can set or change the preferred availability zone after cluster creation.

errMsg.lessNodes: Invalid node count! You have selected {{nodeCount}} nodes. To support the chosen fault tolerance {{faultToleranceNeeded}} nodes are required. Update your selection to proceed.
errMsg.lessNodesDedicated: Invalid node count! You have selected {{nodeCount}} T-server nodes. To support the chosen fault tolerance {{faultToleranceNeeded}} T-server nodes are required. Update your selection to proceed.
